channel.title: Comments on: Master Data Services (Second Edition) â€“ Review
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Koen Verbeeck
item.dc:creator: Koen Verbeeck
item.description: MDS is different from SCD's in the sense that MDS usually does not store history, but just the actual state of a domain entity. It's just another source for the DWH in my opinion.
item.content:encoded: MDS is different from SCD’s in the sense that MDS usually does not store history, but just the actual state of a domain entity. It’s just another source for the DWH in my opinion.

item.title: By: Steven Neumersky
item.dc:creator: Steven Neumersky
item.description:
I agree on all points. I am rereading this in context and comparison to the MS White Papers on EIM.
Upon first glance, I felt as though I needed to "unlearn" my understandings of Kimball's SCDs in order to use MDS correctly. It threw me for a loop until I looked at it for what it is....an interactive, top down product.....not a bottom up product catered to automated, hands off ETL (although, through subscription views, that is the ultimate output goal).
item.content:encoded:
I agree on all points. I am rereading this in context and comparison to the MS White Papers on EIM.

Upon first glance, I felt as though I needed to “unlearn” my understandings of Kimball’s SCDs in order to use MDS correctly. It threw me for a loop until I looked at it for what it is….an interactive, top down product…..not a bottom up product catered to automated, hands off ETL (although, through subscription views, that is the ultimate output goal).
